abstracts.cdata!:
The Universalization of Basic Education
            Project aims at improving coverage, and equity at the
            primary school level, as well as improving the quality of
            education. It will further seek to facilitate the design,
            and execution of a program to enhance cultural diversity,
            and pluralism as specified by the Guatemalan Peace Accords,
            and the National Congress on Cultural Policies. The four
            main components will: 1) support universal access to primary
            education by expanding the primary schools' enrollment
            capacity in rural areas, and marginal communities, through
            the National Community-managed Program for Educational
            Development (PRONADE). Under this program, rural communities
            will receive financing for development of new school
            facilities, based on a participatory criteria. Economic
            assistance/scholarships will be available for poor families,
            with an emphasis on girls attendance; 2) focus on improving
            the quality of education, by strengthening multi-grade
            strategies, and bilingual education; providing educational
            materials; and, training teachers in new methodologies,
            including educational content, and bilingual curricula
            development; 3) support the institutional strengthening of
            the Ministry of Culture and Sports (MCS), in coordination
            with the Ministry of Education (MINEDUC), to attain cultural
            diversity, and pluralism. The component includes capacity
            building, decentralization of MCS cultural education
            services to the municipal level; and, design of a national
            cultural resources information system; and, 4) support the
            improvement of MINEDUC managerial, and administrative
            capacities, for decentralization at the departmental, and
            local level, emphasizing on strengthening the Bilingual
            Education Directorate. It also includes training to
            community associations, and continued development of the
            education management information system.
